title: 107_hr2408
content: The Act is titled the "Yankton Sioux Tribe and Santee Sioux Tribe Equitable Compensation Act" and its purpose is outlined in the findings and purposes section. The "Flood Control Act of 1944" approved the Pick-Sloan Missouri River Basin program for economic development, irrigation, flood protection, and other purposes. The impounded waters for the Fort Randall and Gavins Point projects have flooded fertile bottom lands along the Missouri River. The Fort Randall and Gavins Point projects, part of the Pick-Sloan program, generate hydropower and impound water, but the Yankton Sioux Tribe and Santee Sioux Tribe reservations remain undeveloped. The United States Army Corps of Engineers took Indian lands for the Fort Randall and Gavins Point projects through condemnation proceedings, denying the Yankton Sioux Tribe and Santee Sioux Tribe compensation for direct damages. The tribes also did not receive just compensation for the taking of productive agricultural lands. The Yankton Sioux Tribe and Santee Sioux Tribe were not fairly compensated for the taking of their lands for the Fort Randall Dam and Reservoir. The Yankton Sioux Tribe should receive $23,023,743 for 2,851.40 acres taken, and the Santee Sioux Tribe should receive $4,789,010 for 593.10 acres taken near the Santee village. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The term "Indian tribe" refers to the definition in the Indian Self-Determination and Education Assistance Act. The "Santee Sioux Tribe" is the tribe in Nebraska, and the "Yankton Sioux Tribe" is the tribe in South Dakota. SEC. 4. YANKTON SIOUX TRIBE DEVELOPMENT TRUST FUND. Establishment of the Yankton Sioux Tribe Development Trust Fund in the Treasury of the United States to consist of deposited amounts under the Act. Funding includes a deposit of $23,023,743 from the General Fund of the Treasury on the 11th fiscal year after enactment, along with additional interest accrued on the deposited amount. The Secretary of the Treasury will invest the Trust Fund in interest-bearing obligations of the United States. Interest from investments will be deposited back into the Fund. Starting on the 11th fiscal year after enactment, the Secretary will withdraw interest annually for the Tribe. The Secretary of the Treasury will transfer interest from the Trust Fund to the Secretary of the Interior for the Yankton Sioux Tribe's use. The payments can only be made after the tribe adopts a tribal plan. The Yankton Sioux Tribe must use payments for tribal projects under their plan. The Treasury Secretary cannot transfer or withdraw funds deposited, except in specific cases. SEC. 5. SANTEE SIOUX TRIBE DEVELOPMENT TRUST FUND. Establishment of the "Santee Sioux Tribe Development Trust Fund" in the Treasury of the United States to consist of deposited amounts under the Act. Funding includes a deposit of $4,789,010 from the General Fund of the Treasury on the 11th fiscal year after enactment, along with additional interest accrued on the deposited amount. The "Santee Sioux Tribe Development Trust Fund" is established in the Treasury of the United States with an initial deposit of $4,789,010 from the General Fund. The Secretary of the Treasury is responsible for investing the Fund and depositing interest back into it. Starting on the 11th fiscal year after enactment, the Secretary will withdraw interest annually. The Secretary of the Treasury will transfer interest from the Fund to the Secretary of the Interior for the Santee Sioux Tribe. The payments can only be made upon request by the tribe and after adopting a tribal plan. The Santee Sioux Tribe must use payments for tribal projects under section 6, and the Treasury Secretary cannot transfer or withdraw deposited amounts except in specific cases. SEC. 6. TRIBAL PLANS. The tribal council of Yankton Sioux and Santee Sioux Tribes must prepare a tribal plan within 24 months of this Act. The plan outlines how payments will be used for economic, infrastructure, educational, health, and social welfare purposes. The plan must be reviewed and revised by the tribal council. The tribal council must provide the tribe with a copy of the tribal plan for review before finalization. The council can update the plan annually with input from tribe members. Consultation with the Secretary of the Interior and Health and Human Services is required during plan preparation. The tribes' activities in carrying out tribal plans are audited annually as part of a single-agency audit required by the Office of Management and Budget circular A-133. Auditors determine if funds were used in accordance with the tribal plans. The audits of tribal activities are included in the written findings and published in the tribal council's minutes. Per capita payments to members of the Yankton Sioux Tribe and Santee Sioux Tribe of Nebraska are prohibited under this Act. SEC. 7. ELIGIBILITY OF TRIBE FOR PROGRAMS AND SERVICES: Payments to Yankton Sioux Tribe or Santee Sioux Tribe under this Act won't reduce or deny entitled services. Payments are tax-exempt and won't affect power rates. SEC. 8. STATUTORY CONSTRUCTION. This Act does not affect any water or treaty rights of Indian tribes, or the authority of the Secretary of the Interior. SEC. 9. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Funds necessary for the Act's implementation are authorized. SEC. 10. EXTINGUISHMENT OF CLAIMS. Upon depositing funds under sections 4(b) and 5(b), all monetary claims by the Yankton Sioux Tribe or the Santee Sioux Tribe of Nebraska against the United States for land loss related to the Fort Randall and Gavins Point projects shall be extinguished.
